Last Of 'Big Four' Hits Ideal

"Our ideal is going to destroy us
With the campaign fund total at
nearly half of the sustaining drive
goal of $750,000, the University will
realize additional student support
from two new sources, it was made
known last Saturday. Abraham Edel:man, chairman of the June Week
Committee, announced that the entire profits of the 1936 June Week
will go to the University Campaign,
and a plan is under consideration by
members of the Senior Class, by
which the class will take out group
insurance, making the Hopkins the
beneficiary. The latest figures on the
drive, released late yesterday, revealed the fund's total at $357,485
This is the first time in the history
of the University that groups have
donated profits of a celebration to
the Hopkins proper, campus leaders
declare, and the group insurance plan
is exciting comment in camus circles.
Campaign activity is now under
way on all fronts, it was announced
through the office of P. Stewart Macauley, secretary of the University.
Alumni committees have been organized in many large cities, including
Philadelphia, Wilmington, New York
and Chicago, and these committees
will soon report progress in their districts.
Undergraduate
committeemen,
meeting last Thursday in the Board
room of Remsen Hall, were able to
report success to the extent of several hundred dollars in solicited
pledges. Dr. Bowman addressed the
meeting, emphasizing the importance
of student representation no matter
how little the amount of the donation.
Among the larger ,donations which
helped the total to swell by sixty thousand dollars in the past week of activity are included a contribution of
$15,000 given 'anonymously, and two
contributions of $1500, one from The
Hub, and the other from the Louis
T. Beaumont Trust Fund.

the

era, unless

we

can

change our ideal," said Dr. Howard
A. Kelly, last surviving member of
the Hopkins' "Big Four", as he discussed the present status of Science
and Religion in tudents' life before
the members of the dormitory last
week.
Dr. Kelly feels that the common
worship of science in this age is going
to bring about a tremendous downfall in society.
"I am not pleading for religion,"
he said, "but for investigation of it
and to give it a fair try."
He showed that the people who
worship science do not really worship
the accomplishments of science, but
worship the totality of science.
"It is the spiritual values that are
most real," he said, "not the material things. It is the way all through
life and all through eternity that
makes life so real."
After his talk, Dr. Kelly led a discussion with the group. Several questions, including the relationship between Evolution and the Bible, the
place of science as an emotional outlet similar to religion, were thrashed
out under his leadership.

The votes cast for the Democratic
party were only 33.9 per cent of the

Mr. Roose-

velt's personal popularity exceeds that
of his party. The Republican party
was second in adherents with 23.2

Nine candidates received votes in
the poll. Second to Roosevelt were
Norman Thomas, Socialist, and Alf
M. Landon, Republican,

each

tied

with 16.3 per cent, and after them in
the order named were Earl Browder,
Communist; Henry Breckenbridge,
Democrat; Arthur H. Vandenburg,
Republican; Broadus Mitchell, Socialist professor of political science
at the Hopkins; Herbert Hoover, Republican; and Milton Waldman, Socialist leader.
Among other developments of the
poll was the 72.1 per cent of the ballots cast in the negative for the question, "If a Farmer-Labor Party is
formed, I will support it in preference
to the one checked above."
If the precedent set by the success
of NEWS-LETTER polls in the past
means
anything, Roosevelt
will
probably be defeated in the coming
election. Four years ago in a Hopkins straw vote Hoover won, while
Roosevelt was successful in the national elections. Last year Albert C.
Ritchie and Professor Mitchell led in
the Hopkins straw vote for the governorship of Maryland. Harry W. Nice
won the election. This year Roosevelt
has won in the straw vote. Various
political geniuses are drawing their
conclusions from this series of circumstances.

Honorary Journalistic Fraternity To
Elect Officers Also; Zierler
Issues Statement
The Johns Hopkins chapter of Pi
Delta Epsilon, honorary journalistic
fraternity, will meet tomorrow to
elect new members and officers for
the coming year, Kenneth Zierler,
president, has announced.
In summing up the activities of Pi
D. E. during the past year, Zierler
said, "The high spot of the season
was, of course, Arthur Garfield Hays'
address at an assembly last fall. Certainly, the student body appreciated
this speaker. Under our auspices Mr.
Stewart Macaulay addressed the student journalists and gave some valuable tips. Other lectures have been
planned."
Besides Zierler, members of Pi D.
E. include Robert Levi, Clifford
Bruck, Robert Watkins, Mead Johnson, Henry Severn, Clarence Weimer,
David Levy, Jesse Borden, and Irving
Leberfeld.

President Of Club

Philip W. Guild, Cadet Major of
the Johns Hopkins unit of the Reserve
Officers' Training Corps, won four
awards at the final review of the
battalion late Monday afternoon. A
downpour of rain interrupted the
half-concluded
ceremonies
which
President Isaiah Bowman, BrigadierGeneral Charles D. Roberts, and other distinguished guests were reviewing.
Before the break in the weather
occurred, compttition for the best
drilled private and the officer most
adept at the saber manual was held.
Medals were awarded to J. E. Snodgrass and Philip Guild, respectively.
The annual competition to determine
the best drilled company was called
off.
The guests and the battalion went
into Room 1, Remsen Hall, where Lt.
Col. Gregory Hoisington presided to
present awards and introduce the
guests of honor, General Roberts and
President Bowman.
Guild Receives High Honors
While a crowded audience expressed continued approval and amazement, Philip Guild marched forward
to receive the first three awards, for
excellence in military efficiency, in
rifle marksmanship, and for scholastic attainment in military tactics-a medal, a large silver cup, and a
saber. Guild is a Senior in the College of Arts and Sciences and a member of Phi Beta Kappa.
Samuel Rittenhouse received the
Major Enoch Barton Garey medal
for excellence in field engineering,
and Norman Kemp a medal for superior work in machine gunnery. William Hazlett, captain of A Company,
received an award for leadership and
soldierly bearing, while Frank Hall
was presented an award for the best
study and paper on the Maryland Soldiers at the Battle of Long Island.
Major Coffin Given Present
Through Guild the R. 0. T. C. presented Major Frank Coffin, who is
retiring from duty as an instructor
at the Hopkins, a dressing set.
President Bowman delivered a
short address in which he declared
he thought the R. 0. T. C. was beneficial for good citizenship.
General Roberts's address, in which
he explained the necessity of military reserves, concluded the exercises.

A June Week crowded with social
high-lights will get under way on
Tuesday, June 2. The five days of
gala celebration will feature numerous dances, two of which will stand
out because of the presence of Jimmy
Lunceford and Benny Goodman, listed among America's top-rate dance
band maestros. June Week tickets are
on sale every day in Levering Hall
for $11, according to Abraham Edelman, chairman of the June Week
Committee. The value of the week's
entertainment totals $20.35 if tickets
to the various affairs are purchased
individually.
Next Saturday will witness the
drawing of a free June Week ticket
at the lacrosse game, it was announced. All spectators at the game
will be permitted to draw for the free
ticket, which will allow admission
to the entire June Week program.
The schedule of events is as follows:
TUESDAY, JUNE 2
The Interfraternity Board night
club party featuring Al Shirey and
his International Entertainers will be
held at the Alcazar at nine o'clock.
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 3
Benny Goodman will play at the
Senior Ball at the Alcazar at nine
o'clock. Featured with him is Helen
Ward, and the renowned Trio.
THURSDAY, JUNE 4
The varsity baseball team will play
the alumni at the field in the afternoon, foolwing which there will be a
dance at Levering Hall from four to
six, with a local band furnishing the
music. The seniors will hold their annual banquet at six at the Lord Baltimore Hotel. At eight o'clock the
Hopkins lacrosse team win oppose
the alumni at Homewood field, and
there will be a dance at the Lord Baltimore following the game to last until two o'clock.
FRIDAY, JUNE 5
A Tea dance will be held at Levering Hall in the afternoon. In the evening Jimmy Lunneford will provide
the music for the Junior Prom at the
Alcazar.
SATURDAY, JUNE 6
The afternoon and evening will be
spent at the Annapolis Road Club
where June Week revellers will indulge in swimming, tennis, boating,
golf, and in the evening a dance to

Cross Picked As
O.D.K. President
New President Recently Tapped Will
Succeed David Levy As Head
Of 0. D. K.
Hershner Cross, president-elect of
the Student Council for 1936-37, was
elected president of Beta Circle of
Omicron Delta Kappa, national honorary activities fraternity, at a meeting held Friday. Cross was recently
tapped by 0. D. K. at the Spring Tap
Day assembly two weeks ago.
The other officers elected were Theodore Graziano, vice-president; Gerald
Branower, secretary; and James
Bradford, treasurer. These men and
two others, Robert Watkins and W.
E. Holt Maulsby, will compose the
active membership for next year.
The graduating members of 0. D.
K. are nine in number. They are D.
Weimer,
Mead Johnson, Clarence
John C. MacGill, David Levy, Leonard Emmert, William Hazlett, Paul
Umbarger, Robert Levy, and Henry
D. Severn.

By SIG SAFIER
"April showers bring May flowers"—these same blossoms usher in
our "long-awaited" exams.
The R. 0. T. C. unit was certainly
affected by showers—they were actually double-crossed. Who would
ever predict rain on a May day that
is sunny and clear up until 3 o'clock?
We who were witnesses to part of
the spectacle were, am pretty sure,
deprived of seeing the rest of what
would probably prove to be the best
R. 0. T. C. review held on this campus in years. Much credit is due
Cadet Major Phillip W. Guild, who
ran off with the individual awards by
winning four of the eighth prizes.
Major Coffin, who was presented
with a traveling man's shaving set
when it was announced that he had
been transferred to Fort Myers, was
quite surprised when the zipper on
the case opened. The Major's past
experiences with zippers apparently
had not been very successful. "It
works," said the Major surprisingly
when it opened.

Monday afforded this correspondent a chance to size up the femininity with which the Hopkins lads are
accusomed to be seen—and I was surprised. Fellows who appeared to be
definite social blanks had some of
the prettiest girls. On the whole all
of the weaker sex present were fitting of the Hopkins man—"that's
sayin' somepin." Judging from the
success of this year's review, in spite
of rain, those that follow should be
"tremendously" successful.

Interfrat Pact To Be Enforced For First Time
In History
For the first time in its history,
the Interfraternity Board has received the backing of the Administration in enforcing its annual rushing
agreement. A letter from Dean Edward J. Berry to William J. McFeely,
Jr., president of the fraternity organization, revealed that the Administration is in favor of punishing infractions of rushing rules. His
message follows:
"Dear Mr. McFeely:
I have read and approved of the
ruhing agreement for 1936-1937 which
I understand you to say had received
the approval:of *all the fraternities
comprising the Interfraternity Board.
"If I am right in this assumption
I am glad to give my approval to this
agreement and to say that the Administration will stand squarely behind the enforcement of any penalty
which the Board may decide upon
after due consideration of particular
cases of infractions of the agreement. "Verk truly yours,
E. W. Berry."
Commenting on Dean Berry's statement, McFeely said, "We feel it a
great victory to have at last gained
real power in enforcing the agreement. The Interfrat Board has not
lost its status on the campus if ridiculous incapacity and stands ready
to give rushees and rushers guarantees of fairness that they could only
hope for previously."

With the campaign fund total at
nearly half of the sustaining drive
goal of $750,000, the University will
realize additional student support
from two new sources, it was made
known last Saturday. Abraham Edel:man, chairman of the June Week
Committee, announced that the entire profits of the 1936 June Week
will go to the University Campaign,
and a plan is under consideration by
members of the Senior Class, by
which the class will take out group
insurance, making the Hopkins the
beneficiary. The latest figures on the
drive, released late yesterday, revealed the fund's total at $357,485
This is the first time in the history
of the University that groups have
donated profits of a celebration to
the Hopkins proper, campus leaders
declare, and the group insurance plan
is exciting comment in camus circles.
Campaign activity is now under
way on all fronts, it was announced
through the office of P. Stewart Macauley, secretary of the University.
Alumni committees have been organized in many large cities, including
Philadelphia, Wilmington, New York
and Chicago, and these committees
will soon report progress in their districts.
Undergraduate
committeemen,
meeting last Thursday in the Board
room of Remsen Hall, were able to
report success to the extent of several hundred dollars in solicited
pledges. Dr. Bowman addressed the
meeting, emphasizing the importance
of student representation no matter
how little the amount of the donation.
Among the larger ,donations which
helped the total to swell by sixty thousand dollars in the past week of activity are included a contribution of
$15,000 given 'anonymously, and two
contributions of $1500, one from The
Hub, and the other from the Louis
T. Beaumont Trust Fund.

change our ideal," said Dr. Howard
A. Kelly, last surviving member of
the Hopkins' "Big Four", as he discussed the present status of Science
and Religion in tudents' life before
the members of the dormitory last
week.
Dr. Kelly feels that the common
worship of science in this age is going
to bring about a tremendous downfall in society.
"I am not pleading for religion,"
he said, "but for investigation of it
and to give it a fair try."
He showed that the people who
worship science do not really worship
the accomplishments of science, but
worship the totality of science.
"It is the spiritual values that are
most real," he said, "not the material things. It is the way all through
life and all through eternity that
makes life so real."
After his talk, Dr. Kelly led a discussion with the group. Several questions, including the relationship between Evolution and the Bible, the
place of science as an emotional outlet similar to religion, were thrashed
out under his leadership.

Honorary Journalistic Fraternity To
Elect Officers Also; Zierler
Issues Statement
The Johns Hopkins chapter of Pi
Delta Epsilon, honorary journalistic
fraternity, will meet tomorrow to
elect new members and officers for
the coming year, Kenneth Zierler,
president, has announced.
In summing up the activities of Pi
D. E. during the past year, Zierler
said, "The high spot of the season
was, of course, Arthur Garfield Hays'
address at an assembly last fall. Certainly, the student body appreciated
this speaker. Under our auspices Mr.
Stewart Macaulay addressed the student journalists and gave some valuable tips. Other lectures have been
planned."
Besides Zierler, members of Pi D.
E. include Robert Levi, Clifford
Bruck, Robert Watkins, Mead Johnson, Henry Severn, Clarence Weimer,
David Levy, Jesse Borden, and Irving
Leberfeld.

President Of Club

Philip W. Guild, Cadet Major of
the Johns Hopkins unit of the Reserve
Officers' Training Corps, won four
awards at the final review of the
battalion late Monday afternoon. A
downpour of rain interrupted the
half-concluded
ceremonies
which
President Isaiah Bowman, BrigadierGeneral Charles D. Roberts, and other distinguished guests were reviewing.
Before the break in the weather
occurred, compttition for the best
drilled private and the officer most
adept at the saber manual was held.
Medals were awarded to J. E. Snodgrass and Philip Guild, respectively.
The annual competition to determine
the best drilled company was called
off.
The guests and the battalion went
into Room 1, Remsen Hall, where Lt.
Col. Gregory Hoisington presided to
present awards and introduce the
guests of honor, General Roberts and
President Bowman.
Guild Receives High Honors
While a crowded audience expressed continued approval and amazement, Philip Guild marched forward
to receive the first three awards, for
excellence in military efficiency, in
rifle marksmanship, and for scholastic attainment in military tactics-a medal, a large silver cup, and a
saber. Guild is a Senior in the College of Arts and Sciences and a member of Phi Beta Kappa.
Samuel Rittenhouse received the
Major Enoch Barton Garey medal
for excellence in field engineering,
and Norman Kemp a medal for superior work in machine gunnery. William Hazlett, captain of A Company,
received an award for leadership and
soldierly bearing, while Frank Hall
was presented an award for the best
study and paper on the Maryland Soldiers at the Battle of Long Island.
Major Coffin Given Present
Through Guild the R. 0. T. C. presented Major Frank Coffin, who is
retiring from duty as an instructor
at the Hopkins, a dressing set.
President Bowman delivered a
short address in which he declared
he thought the R. 0. T. C. was beneficial for good citizenship.
General Roberts's address, in which
he explained the necessity of military reserves, concluded the exercises.

A June Week crowded with social
high-lights will get under way on
Tuesday, June 2. The five days of
gala celebration will feature numerous dances, two of which will stand
out because of the presence of Jimmy
Lunceford and Benny Goodman, listed among America's top-rate dance
band maestros. June Week tickets are
on sale every day in Levering Hall
for $11, according to Abraham Edelman, chairman of the June Week
Committee. The value of the week's
entertainment totals $20.35 if tickets
to the various affairs are purchased
individually.
Next Saturday will witness the
drawing of a free June Week ticket
at the lacrosse game, it was announced. All spectators at the game
will be permitted to draw for the free
ticket, which will allow admission
to the entire June Week program.
The schedule of events is as follows:
TUESDAY, JUNE 2
The Interfraternity Board night
club party featuring Al Shirey and
his International Entertainers will be
held at the Alcazar at nine o'clock.
WEDNESDAY, JUNE 3
Benny Goodman will play at the
Senior Ball at the Alcazar at nine
o'clock. Featured with him is Helen
Ward, and the renowned Trio.
THURSDAY, JUNE 4
The varsity baseball team will play
the alumni at the field in the afternoon, foolwing which there will be a
dance at Levering Hall from four to
six, with a local band furnishing the
music. The seniors will hold their annual banquet at six at the Lord Baltimore Hotel. At eight o'clock the
Hopkins lacrosse team win oppose
the alumni at Homewood field, and
there will be a dance at the Lord Baltimore following the game to last until two o'clock.
FRIDAY, JUNE 5
A Tea dance will be held at Levering Hall in the afternoon. In the evening Jimmy Lunneford will provide
the music for the Junior Prom at the
Alcazar.
SATURDAY, JUNE 6
The afternoon and evening will be
spent at the Annapolis Road Club
where June Week revellers will indulge in swimming, tennis, boating,
golf, and in the evening a dance to

Hershner Cross, president-elect of
the Student Council for 1936-37, was
elected president of Beta Circle of
Omicron Delta Kappa, national honorary activities fraternity, at a meeting held Friday. Cross was recently

Day assembly two weeks ago.
The other officers elected were Theodore Graziano, vice-president; Gerald
Branower, secretary; and James
Bradford, treasurer. These men and
two others, Robert Watkins and W.
E. Holt Maulsby, will compose the
active membership for next year.
The graduating members of 0. D.

Weimer,

John C. MacGill, David Levy, Leonard Emmert, William Hazlett, Paul
Umbarger, Robert Levy, and Henry
D. Severn.

In closing I should like to say that
the thing student activities most need
here at Hopkins is the genuine interest of everyone taking part in them.
This interest should work to secure
the best men for officers in each activity, men who are interested and
will do the work. Interest should not
stop with the election of officers but
should carry through and insist that
the job is well done. Only in this way
win activities be well run and beneficial to those taking part in them.

By SIG SAFIER
"April showers bring May flowers"—these same blossoms usher in
our "long-awaited" exams.
The R. 0. T. C. unit was certainly
affected by showers—they were actually double-crossed. Who would
ever predict rain on a May day that
is sunny and clear up until 3 o'clock?
We who were witnesses to part of
the spectacle were, am pretty sure,
deprived of seeing the rest of what
would probably prove to be the best
R. 0. T. C. review held on this campus in years. Much credit is due
Cadet Major Phillip W. Guild, who
ran off with the individual awards by
winning four of the eighth prizes.
Major Coffin, who was presented
with a traveling man's shaving set
when it was announced that he had
been transferred to Fort Myers, was
quite surprised when the zipper on
the case opened. The Major's past
experiences with zippers apparently
had not been very successful. "It
works," said the Major surprisingly
when it opened.

Monday afforded this correspondent a chance to size up the femininity with which the Hopkins lads are
accusomed to be seen—and I was surprised. Fellows who appeared to be
definite social blanks had some of
the prettiest girls. On the whole all
of the weaker sex present were fitting of the Hopkins man—"that's
sayin' somepin." Judging from the
success of this year's review, in spite
of rain, those that follow should be
"tremendously" successful.
For your approval we inaugurate:

secretary to the Education Department, is due to make a matrimonial
plunge in August?
That Dr. John L. Ulrich of the
Zoology Department is carrying on
some very interesting work on the
nerves of cats and mice?
That Dr. Ulrich is in need of a
willing, reliable student assistant.
This work is excellent preparation
for pre-medical students?

Interfrat Pact To Be Enforced For First Time
In History
For the first time in its history,
the Interfraternity Board has received the backing of the Administration in enforcing its annual rushing
agreement. A letter from Dean Edward J. Berry to William J. McFeely,
Jr., president of the fraternity organization, revealed that the Administration is in favor of punishing infractions of rushing rules. His
message follows:
"Dear Mr. McFeely:
I have read and approved of the
ruhing agreement for 1936-1937 which
I understand you to say had received
the approval:of *all the fraternities
comprising the Interfraternity Board.
"If I am right in this assumption
I am glad to give my approval to this
agreement and to say that the Administration will stand squarely behind the enforcement of any penalty
which the Board may decide upon
after due consideration of particular
cases of infractions of the agreement. "Verk truly yours,
E. W. Berry."
Commenting on Dean Berry's statement, McFeely said, "We feel it a
great victory to have at last gained
real power in enforcing the agreement. The Interfrat Board has not
lost its status on the campus if ridiculous incapacity and stands ready
to give rushees and rushers guarantees of fairness that they could only
hope for previously."
